_meanings:
{@--1@} Much, 
abundantly, very much, exceedingly,
greatly, in a high degree.

having many syllables,
polysyllabic (as a word).
a cow that has often calved.

a kind
of mendicant who lives in a
strange town and maintains 
himself with alms got by begging
from door to door; <ab>cf.</ab> {#kuwIcaka#}.

a term applied to
the Ṛgveda.

having many
verses. ({#-caH#}) one conversant with
the Ṛgveda.

of a
long standing, old, ancient.

{2} a
bud of the Campaka tree.

knowing much, 
wellinformed, possessed of great 
knowledge.

{1} attended with many gifts
or donations.

{1} having many faults or
defects, very wicked or sinful.

{2} (in law)
involving many counts, as a plaint.

{1} highly esteemed or prized, 
valued, respected.

gift given by a superior to an 
inferior.
a place where many roads meet.

a place where
several roads meet.

a large sum of money, heavy or
costly price.

very powerful, heroic,
a great warrior.

presenting many difficulties, attended with
many dangers.

possessing much rice; {#tatpuruza#}
{#karmaDAraya yenAhaM syAM bahuvrIhiH#} <ls>Udb.</ls>
(where it is also the name of the
compound).

one of the four
principal kinds of compounds in
Sanskrit. In it, two or more nouns
in apposition to each other are
compounded, the attributive 
member (whether a noun or an 
adjective) being placed first, and made
to qualify another substantive, and
neither of the two members 
separately, but the sense of the whole
compound, qualifies that 
substantive. This compound is adjectival
in character, but there are several
instances of Bahuvrīhi compounds
which have come to be regarded
and used as nouns (their 
application being restricted by usage to
particular individuals); {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} {#cakrapARi#},
{#SaSiSeKara, pItAMbara, caturmuKa, trinetra#}, 
{#kusumaSara#} &c.

possessed of
great pith or essence, substantial.
